Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge erred in finding the Applicant did not satisfy the residency requirement under section 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Applicant was physically present in Canada for 507 days within the four-year period, falling short of the required 1,095 days
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Citizenship Judge's decision
Court_Ruling: Federal Court upheld the Citizenship Judge's decision
Defendant_Behavior: Failed to meet the minimum physical presence requirement for citizenship
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error in the residency determination by the Citizenship Judge
Assessment_Factor: Physical presence test as an allowable method to determine residency
Procedural_Issue: Review of administrative decision by the Federal Court
Evidence_Used: Record of physical presence in Canada (507 days)
Application_Basis: Quantitative residency requirement based on physical presence
Evidence_Assessed: Insufficient evidence to meet exceptions or qualitative criteria for residency
Relief_Sought: Overturning of the citizenship application denial
Governing_Rule: An applicant must accumulate 1,095 days of residence in Canada within four years
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient documentation or proof to establish additional residency beyond 507 days
Cause_Description: Applicant challenged the denial of citizenship due to alleged errors in residency determination
Evidence_Handling: The Judge applied the physical presence test and assessed available evidence of residency
Evidence_Issues: No evidence presented to support exceptions or alternative qualitative assessment of residency
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant â€“ only 507 days of physical presence recorded
Evidence_Assessment: The evidence showed insufficient physical presence; no credible basis to invoke exceptions
Decision_Rationale: The decision was reasonable as the applicant failed to meet the statutory residency requirement
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to provide adequate evidence of additional days of residence
